Posts.Content: My husband is having his cath out tomorrow (yay) I'm going shopping now. What pads should I get him to see him through the next two weeks. Sorry if this has been posted already but I'm on my phone and it's hard to trawl through. Also a heartfelt thanks to all the "cancer boys". Your advice has been invaluable to me and him by proxy
Posts.Title: Best post surgery pads

Posts.Content: My husband is also going through this. He had prostate and lymph nodes removed in May and now his left leg gets really swollen from groin to foot. He's really uncomfortable. He did go to the ER last month when it was insanely swollen. They didn't find any clots and didn't offer and treatment suggestions or ideas to treat it. I'm trying to find a lymphedema specialist for him now. He's pretty miserable about it.
Posts.Title: Swelling in one leg

Posts.Content: Thanks Mikia
Posts.Title: Insight into after surgery from a wife's perspective

Posts.Content: Thanks Mikia
Posts.Title: Insight into after surgery from a wife's perspective

Posts.Content: That's great to hear. My husband just had his prostatectomy yesterday. He's 61 and I'm 46. We're taking it one day at a time but so far this whole thing has made us closer than ever.

Posts.Title: Insight into after surgery from a wife's perspective

Posts.Content: So we went to see the surgeon who'll be performing my husband's Da Vinci. We were very happy with him (Dr Tuerk in Boston) They're also going to take out his lymph nodes. My husband isn't that proactive in researching what he'll need after surgery so he's leaving all that to me. Any advice on what sort of pads to buy him? Things that will make the days post surgery a little easier for him? He's expecting to be back at work after two weeks but he has to drive 100 miles each way and is a pilot so it's a fairly active job in the pre flight aspect at least. I've told him that I think two weeks might be a little optimistic. Some stats on him. He's just turned 60. Gleason score of 6, PSA 5 but he's been treated as having an aggressive cancer due to the volume of it. Cancer was found in every core they biopsied, hence the lymph node removal.
Posts.Title: Easing the prostatectomy experience for husband

Posts.Content: No he means 2 weeks from the date of surgery which I just can't see happening. He's most worried about having the cathether in (and out)
Posts.Title: Easing the prostatectomy experience for husband

Posts.Title: Easing the prostatectomy experience for husband

Posts.Content: My husband initially went to Mass General for an extended appointment / case conference. We were really impressed with them. They said that in his case surgery was the best option. We ended up going to Dr Tuerk at St Elizabeth. He just had the surgery yesterday and his home now. Dr Tuerk has a world class reputation and we wouldn't hesitate to recommend him.
Posts.Title: What clinics/MDs around Boston have the most advanced technology?...

Posts.Content: His most recent PSA was 4.5
Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: We live in MA. My husband has just turned 60. He has no actual symptoms. His father had prostate cancer and his primary care doc found a ridge during his annual exam. It was the same urologist who did the biopsy. He's had an MRI and then an Atermis biopsy. I'm getting a copy of the MRI sent to me. Whilst we're not discounting HIFU or indeed any other treatment, the doc we saw who is apparently well known didn't exactly had a good bedside manner.
Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: Just in case it's any help to you chaps. Viagra and cialis aren't covered under our insurance. After a lengthy talk with my insurance company (UHC), they told me that they have a contracted rate with CVS whereby it's still not covered but it's a hell of a lot cheaper. I did have to push for this and the initial answers were "no it's not covered". Sure enough I filled the RX yesterday and with his pain meds, bactrim, stool softener and cialis it only came to $75. So if you're having issues I highly recommend you talk to your insurance company about the contracted rate and which pharmacy they have it with. Hope this helped.
Posts.Title: Prescription tip

Posts.Content: My husband initially went to Mass General for an extended appointment / case conference. We were really impressed with them. They said that in his case surgery was the best option. We ended up going to Dr Tuerk at St Elizabeth. He just had the surgery yesterday and his home now. Dr Tuerk has a world class reputation and we wouldn't hesitate to recommend him.
Posts.Title: What clinics/MDs around Boston have the most advanced technology?...

Posts.Content: This is where I get confused. Initially the doc we saw said it was Gleason 7 with 3+4 and then he said it was 3+3 then he said it was mainly 3+3 with some 3+4. I'd taken a note book in to take notes but he was glaring daggers at me and I was so stunned by everything that I didn't take notes. I've spoken to Mass General and they will see him. I'm getting as much of his lab work as I can and Mass General said 3 docs review it all and we'll meet with them. I think it's a radiation oncologist, a urologist oncologist and one other. My husband is understandably very down about it all so I'm setting up the appointments for him and doing as much research as I can so we go in with as full an understanding as we can. I'm trying to encourage him to come on these forums so he can read positive as well as realistic reviews from people like you who have been through it
Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: My husband has recently been diagnosed with prostate cancer. Went we to see his urologist yesterday and he told him he has a stage IIA cancer with gleason score of 7 and genetic markers which make it more aggressive. Its in 90% of the left side of the prostate and clear in the right. So he then says he needs a radical prostatectomy which will leave him impotent and Incontinent. If he doest want that he said he has the option of testosterone suppressing meds which have the same side effects or radiation, same deal. Or he can do nothing and be dead in ten years. Then he throws into conversation that theres a new treatment they do in England called HIFU which has none of those side effects only its not approved in America so for a mere $25k he can do it for him in Mexico. I tried to ask him lots of questions about this new treatment which he did NOT appreciate at all. When I pointed out that I'm British and can take him there for the treatment he said "well he might not be a candidate" and I said "yet for $25k and a trip to mexico he's a candidate with you"? and he just refused to speak to me after that. He was like a used car salesman. I'm urging him to go for a second opinion to look at all our options.
Posts.Title: HIFU - Confusion and frustation

Posts.Content: We live in MA. My husband has just turned 60. He has no actual symptoms. His father had prostate cancer and his primary care doc found a ridge during his annual exam. It was the same urologist who did the biopsy. He's had an MRI and then an Atermis biopsy. I'm getting a copy of the MRI sent to me. Whilst we're not discounting HIFU or indeed any other treatment, the doc we saw who is apparently well known didn't exactly had a good bedside manner.

Posts.Title: cathetar discomfort

Posts.Content: My husband just had his prostatectomy yesterday. They let me into recovery almost as soon as he came round and he was complaining of "I'VE GOT TO PEE NOW" which they said was pretty common and would wear off within 24 hours. He's home now and that sensation has lessened but his cath is causing him a lot of discomfort. He says it's a burning sensation and it makes him really hard to get comfortable for more than a couple of minutes. I know it's early days but is there anything I can do to make him more comfortable? His day bag was filling up really quickly so we put the night bag on instead so he doesn't have to keep getting up to empty it.
Posts.Title: cathetar discomfort

Posts.Content: Thanks Mikem. I was just in CVS and they said lidocaine was rx only so I'm so pleased you've offered an alternative. He says it's "highly discomfortable" when I just asked him. I think he has a decently high pain threshold. He was in a bad accident in the army and has a load of metal in his feet and wrists so is used to chronic pain. If it stays like this I'll call his doc.
Posts.Title: cathetar discomfort
